review.title: A Spatiotemporal Context Definition for Service Adaptation Prediction in a Pervasive Computing Environment
review.abstract: Pervasive systems refers to context-aware systems that can sense their context, and adapt their behavior accordingly to provide adaptable services. Proactive adaptation of such systems allows changing the service and the context based on prediction. However, the definition of the context is still vague and not suitable to prediction. In this paper we discuss and classify previous definitions of context. Then, we present a new definition which allows pervasive systems to understand and predict their contexts. We analyze the essential lines that fall within the context definition, and propose some scenarios to make it clear our approach.

[15] Rather, we can find the concept of "context use," which defines and encompasses all the information that characterizes the user, the environment and the platform. [19] Li [14] defined the spatial context (or geographical context) in three dimensions: (1) the static spatial context, (2) the dynamic spatial context and (3) the internal spatial context. He defined it as follows: • The static spatial context: is geo-spatial information that can have an impact on the user's environment. For example, information about the road network, buildings, shops, interior structures (rooms, offices, homes...). • Dynamic spatial contexts: collect geo-spatial information that is collected, for example, by different types of sensors.

sections.heading: D. Proposed Context Definition
sections.text: Our definition promotes the following axes: (1) the representation of time as the most important feature of the context, (2) the redefinition of the spatial dimension in the ecological integrity of the system and services in a context of use, (3) and the inclusion of the finality of the context in the definition of contextual information. This means that the elements of the context for which the context is used should be taken into account. We then note that the predictive definition is mandatory. Knowledge of the adaptation scenario based on the current context does not require the identification of the spatial or temporal information, neither the finality of the context, nor the attributes are decisive for the prediction. The context in a pervasive system is located around a spatial context and is defined by the three axes mentioned above: (1) time (2) space, and (3) purpose (4) purpose. "
